title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220324newspcr testing to come to an end for most people from next month
story: Testing will continue to play a vital role in Northern Ireland’s response to the COVID- pandemic over the coming months, Health Minister Robin Swann has emphasised. The Minister announced that a more targeted approach to testing will be introduced on a phased basis from next month, with the focus on supporting and protecting those at highest risk of serious illness. Testing will continue to be available for those eligible for COVID- treatments. Under the new policy, PCR testing will cease for most people with symptoms from  April - however free lateral flow tests will continue to be available to the public to use should they develop symptoms of COVID-. Lateral flow tests will also continue to be available free of charge to support those living in, working in or visiting a higher risk setting such as a care home until the end of June, with further review then. The policy covers testing and contact tracing and takes effect from  April. No changes will be introduced until that date. The policy will be kept under review during the period of transition up until the end of June. The Health Minister stated: “The new policy reflects the new realities of the pandemic. While the prevalence of the virus remains at a high level, the risk of serious illness has been signicantly reduced - thanks in no small measure to our vaccination programme and the use of innovative COVID- treatments. “The risk posed by the virus at the present time does not justy testing and isolating large swathes of the population at the levels that we have seen to date in the past two years. Test and trace will continue to have a key role and will be used in a more focused and targeted way to support and protect our most vulnerable. This will be kept under very close review and we will have contingency plans in place so that we can scale up should it be required.” A range of changes will take effect from the  April: PCR testing will no longer be recommended or available for most people with symptoms. It will still be available to support the small group for whom it is recommended for clinical reasons. The PCR home ordering service will remain available for the general public to support those for whom PCR is recommended.Publicly accessible COVID- testing sites will close. Local Health and Social Care Trusts will continue to provide PCR testing to support clinical care.Those with symptoms will be advised to use lateral flow devicesto test instead of booking a PCR. This will be kept under review and could remain in place up to the end of June depending on disease trajectory.Routine asymptomatic testingwill continue to be advised for those living, working and visiting health and social care settings including hospitals and care homes and other high risk settings in line with public health advice. This will be kept under review.Asymptomatic LFD testing for the wider population will cease. Access to free LFDs for this purpose will cease.Routine asymptomatic workplace testing will cease.Routine asymptomatic testing in most educational settingswill cease at the Easter break.Asymptomatic testing in special schools will continue after Easter and will be kept under review. It may continue until the end of June .Routine population contact tracing will be phased out between mid-April and the end of June.  Chief Medical Officer Professor Sir Michael McBride said: “We will continue throughout the transition phase to support and protect our most vulnerable. After these changes are introduced from  April, I would urge people to check on NI Directtesting remains recommended for them - for examplethey are eligible for new treatments. In the coming weeks, the Department will also be working to provide advice and support to those eligible for treatments. It is particularly important that those who are at higher risk of serious illness follow the guidance on getting tested.” The Chief Medical Officer added: “The tools at our disposal to protect people who are at higher risk from COVID- have advanced considerably since the early days of the pandemic. Alongside the vaccine and booster programme, new COVID- treatments continue to be used by patients in Northern Ireland and new treatments are in development. “As the amount of testing across society reduces, our behaviour and actions have an even more important role in preventing transmission and keeping others safe. I urge everyone to continue to follow the public health guidance including continuing to wear a face covering in enclosed settings like public transport and when visiting hospitals and care homes.” The changes do not take effect until  April, and current testing provision will continue until then. Please keep following the latest public health advice as set out on NI Direct.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220325newsrecommendation for post primary pupils to wear facemasks to be scrapped after easter
story: It will no longer be recommended that post-primary pupils wear a face covering in corridors or confined communal areas following the Easter break. This will result in post-primary pupils no longer being recommended to wear a face covering on school premises. The news was confirmed by Education Minister Michelle McIlveen.She said, As was the case with the change relating to the use of face coverings in classrooms, this further change takes place in the context of a broadly improving epidemiological landscape in schools. Nonetheless, COVID continues to circulate in our communities and in our schools and we should continue to reduce the risks of COVID in our schools through the range of other mitigating measures that remain in place to protect all pupils and staff.  It is for this reason thatany inidual wishes to continue to use a face covering anywhere at school, I would encourage them to do so. At this point pupils will still be recommended to wear a face covering when using public or school transport. This position will be kept under review.  A guidance note will issue to schools on this issue later today and my Department’s COVID guidance will be updated to reflect this position.

title: if he hadnt got covid hed be doing well he had a good few years ahead of him
story: Tyrone’s All-Ireland victory in  was bittersweet for the Bell family, just months after super-fan Laurence passed away and his brother James at a Tyrone game. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueLaurence Belland his brother James at a Tyrone game. Laurence passed away last year.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailLAURENCE Bell, from the village of Coagh, was a huge fan of the Tyrone gaelic football team.For most of his adult le, he travelled to see the team play, be it rain or shine, League or Championship.His brother James was always by his side. They were known by fans and ground staff as they rarely missed a game.On February ,  – the same day as his we Kathleen’s birthday – Laurence was admitted to hospital with coronavirus. Exactly a fortnight later, he passed away.His daughter, Cathy Costello, said the hardest thing was not having people he knew and loved with him in hospital.Cathy’s brother – Laurence’s son Declan – died seven months earlier from a heart attack. Restricted numbers were permitted at the wake and funeral.Laurence was  years old, but fit and strong for his age.His daughter Cathy believes “ he hadn’t got Covid, he’d be doing well – he had a good few years ahead of him”.It was bittersweet for her family when Tyrone won the All-Ireland title last September.James, who said he had considered “not going back to football” when Laurence passed, was persuaded to go to the final that day with a friend, but it was an emotional event for all.Laurence’s other son, Conleth, has a poignant memory of his dad being at Tyrone’s winning All-Ireland final in .“After the game was over, he gave me a hug but there was a couple in front of us from Kerry with a young lad of about eight years old, and he was balling and crying.“My father leaned over and he said, ‘Listen, you will win many more. I might never see another one’.”And sadly, he never did.Read More‘I’ve found the whole perception over death from Covid disrespectful – Basil was my brother, people have been so dismissive of his title: the doctors couldnt believe daddy was going into icu because he was doing so well
story: Maureen McPartland spoke of her devastation over not being able to hold a funeral for her father, Tony MitchellExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseTony Mitchell passed away three weeks after testing positive for Covid. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTony Mitchell passed away three weeks after testing positive for Covid.Ralph HewittTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTONY MITCHELLpassed away at Craigavon Area Hospital, Co Armagh, on April , , after testing positive for Covid- three weeks earlier.“Daddy caught it at the start of the pandemic and was very unlucky,” said his daughter Maureen McParland . “If he had caught it now he would have been fine, as we’ve been told.“Everything has changed and people with Covid have had funerals and wakes, and everything that goes with the passing of loved one, whereas we have not.“Our family is trying to come to terms with that. When you hear about Boris Johnson partying four weeks after daddy had died, I just didn#t believe it.”Mr Mitchell made a living by travelling the country to carry out building work. His daughter said he was an “all-rounder” and could put his hand to anything.He was also a successful darts player in the s and competed against famous players such as Bobby George, John Lowe and Jocky Wilson.“My daddy worked right up to the day he went into hospital,” said Ms McParland. “He was fit and healthy. The doctors couldn#t believe that he was going into ICU because he was doing so well.“People think you have to be old or have underlying conditions but it doesn#t matter, the virus still took them.“It’s just very, very unfair. We do all need to get back to normal but we just need to be careful.”Mr Mitchell is survived by daughters Ann, Celia, Philomena and Maureen. He was predeceased by his we Marie.Read MoreMarried for  years, Norman and Winnie Wilkinson both succumbed to Covid within five days of each otherMost ReadStormont department criticised for building title: when the ambulance drove off little did we know there would be no contact with her again
story: When Jemima George died from Covid, her daughter Roberta could not attend the funeral as she too was battling the virusExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her family FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her familyLisa SmythTwitterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJEMIMA George was the heart and soul of her family.Covid- robbed them of a beloved great grandmother. It even snatched away their chance to say a proper goodbye to her.The depth of her family’s grief made headlines earlier this year. Her son-in-law, DUP MP Jim Shannon, challenged Boris Johnson over the lockdown parties at  Downing Street which took place at the same time Ms George , from Newtownards, Co Down, lost her le to the virus in October .“She was so devoted to her family, she lived for her family,” said Mr Shannon.“Birthdays, anniversaries, she never forgot any of them. Christmas was particularly special, and even though she and my father-in-law Robert were pensioners, all their savings would go to the family.“She would have saved up all her coppers, silvers and pounds in a jar and there would be money for everyone at Christmas.Ms George was moved from the emergency department at the Ulster Hospital on the outskirts of east Belfast to a ward where her daughter, Roberta, was also being treated for Covid.Mr Shannon continued: “Roberta couldn’t even go and see her mum even though they were in the same ward.“She was admitted to the hospital on Monday and died on Friday.“It was the horrible and cruel way that she was taken away from us [that hurt so much]. When the ambulance drove off, little did we know there would be no contact with her again.“Roberta couldn’t even go to the funeral because she was still in hospital fighting for her le.“Sandra was left to organise everything because Roberta was so sick. She had to even choose what family and friends could attend the funeral because we were only allowed to have  people there.“That is one thing that has grieved me greatly – how do you draw up a guest list for a funeral ”Read MoreSamantha Willispassed away shortly after giving birth to her fourth childMost ReadStormont department criticised for building Derry park-and-ride which breaches planning title: north belfast security alert watch moment irish foreign minister simon coveney evacuated after vehicle hijacked
story: DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson has led condemnation after Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney was evacuated from an event in North Belfast after a vehicle was hijacked and driven to the venue.Mr Coveney was seen being told by his security team of the incident before telling those in attendance he had to leave.Sources say a van was hijacked on the Shankill Road, a canister placed on board and the driver forced to drive it to Holy Cross Church. Police have put a  metre exclusion zone in place.The driver of the vehicle was in tears inside the venue after alerting security officials to the incident and apologising to attendees for being forced to drive to the site.PSNI officers are currently in attendance at the scene and an army team has been called to assess a device found in the back of the van.Motorists are advised to avoid the area and seek alternative main routes for their journey.Sir Jeffrey condemned the incident, saying those who cling to violence had little support, while Secretary of State Brandon Lewis also said his thoughts were with Mr Coveney.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Mr Coveney was giving an address as part of the Time to Build The Common Ground by the John and Pat Hume Foundation at the Houben Centre on the Crumlin Road.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseIrish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney being evacuated from the John and Pat Hume foundation event in north Belfast. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIrish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney being evacuated from the John and Pat Hume foundation event in north Belfast.After being alerted to a problem, the minister told the audience he had to leave and hoped to be back in a few minutes.However, he was escorted from the area by armed gardaí and members of the PSNI. He is now said to be in a “secure location”. Mr Coveney tweeted: Saddened  frustrated that someone has been attacked  victimised in this way and my thoughts are with him  his family. My thanks to ⁦@PoliceServiceNI.”ExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandPreviousNextNorth Belfast security alert in pictures: Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney evacuated from peace-building event on Crumlin Road" class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePress Eye - Belfast - Northern Ireland - th March The scene at the The Houben Centre on Crumlin Road where a security alert is taking place.It is being reported a van was hijacked on the Shankill, a canister placed on board and the driver forced to drive it to Holy Cross Church, north Belfast.The Irish Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, was speaking at an event for the Hume Foundation in the centre when it had to be evacuated. Mr Coveney was giving a talk for the Hume Foundation on the Crumlin Road.SDLP MP Claire Hanna said the event was abruptly ended after about  minutes when the minister#s security ushered him out of the building.We understand a vehicle was hijacked and explosives or something purporting to be explosives was driven to the venue, she said.Picture By: Arthur Allison Pacemaker Press.Pacemaker Press --:Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney has been moved out of a building in north Belfast amid a security alert. Picture by Jonathan Porter PressEyePress Eye - Belfast - Northern Ireland - th March The scene at the The Houben Centre on Crumlin Road where a security alert is taking place.It is being reported a van was hijacked on the Shankill, a canister placed on board and the driver forced to drive it to Holy Cross Church, north Belfast.The Irish Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, was speaking at an event for the Hume Foundation in the centre when it had to be evacuated. Picture by Jonathan Porter PressEye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePress Eye - Belfast - Northern Ireland - th March The scene at the The Houben Centre on Crumlin Road where a security alert is taking place.It is being reported a van was hijacked on the Shankill, a canister placed on board and the driver forced to drive it to Holy Cross Church, north Belfast.The Irish Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, was speaking at an event for the Hume Foundation in the centre when it had to be evacuated. Picture by Jonathan Porter PressEyeHis keynote speech was due to be followed by a discussion with community leaders, including Alan McBride of WAVE Trauma Centre whose we Sharon, was killed in the Shankill bomb.A funeral was also disrupted in the Ardoyne area because of the incident and the Funeral Mass had to take place on the street.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseFr John Graven carries out a funeral service in the car park at Holy Cross Church in north Belfast due to the security alert in the nearby Houben Centre. Pic: Colm Lenaghan Pacemaker FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFr John Graven carries out a funeral service in the car park at Holy Cross Church in north Belfast due to the security alert in the nearby Houben Centre. Pic: Colm Lenaghan PacemakerTim Attwood, who was moderating the event, said it was “very unfortunate that the event has been cancelled and more importantly the disruption to local community.“The message of the minister in the short time he was speaking and of the John and Pat Hume Foundation is that you can only achieve your goals through peaceful and nonviolent means,” he continued.Security alert latest, Sources saying a van was hijacked on the Shankill Road, a cannister placed on board and the driver forced to drive it to Holy Cross church, the driver said to be very distressed the event organised by the John and Pat Hume Foundation has been abandoned.— Allison MorrisMarch , “Those who think they can drag us back to those dark days are very much mistaken, they are long gone and this will only renew our efforts for peace and reconciliation and our work will continue.”Good to see widespread condemnation of those behind the hijacking and security alert in North Belfast. Most people want to get on with their lives and have no truck with those who cling to violence.Former deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill condemned the actions of those who targeted an event focused on peace, reconciliation and finding common-ground.Those determined to cause instability  disruption will not succeed. Those of us committed to peace will not be deterred.”I condemn the actions of those involved in a security alert at an event focused on peace, reconciliation and finding common-ground. Those determined to cause instability  disruption will not succeed. Those of us committed to peace will not be deterred.— Michelle O’NeillMarch , Her party colleague, North Belfast MP John Finucane, added: “The attack on an event involving Minister Simon Coveney at North Belfast’s Houben Centre today is disgraceful.“Those behind the van hijacking which was left on church grounds have no place in society.“While they try to bring back the past, we will keep working for the future.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ddde .ece AUTOCROP w JPdevice.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ddde .ece AUTOCROP w JPdevice.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ddde .ece AUTOCROP w JPdevice.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ddde .ece AUTOCROP w JPdevice.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "The scene at the The Houben Centre on Crumlin Road where a security alert is taking place. The SDLP’s Spring Conference is set to take place at pm in the Seamus Heaney HomePlace in Bellaghy, Magherafelt.Party leader Colum Eastwood tweeted: “Worrying situation in Belfast today at the Building Common Ground event.These mindless thugs won’t deter the John and Pat Hume Foundation from carrying out their work to further peace.The Hume Foundation is an organisation dedicated to promoting peace and reconciliation. The attack on them and on @simoncoveney this morning is an attempt to drag us back that will never, ever succeed.”Worrying situation in Belfast today at the Building Common Ground event. These mindless thugs won’t deter the John and Pat Hume Foundation from carrying out their work to further peace.— Colum Eastwood 🇺🇦March , Infrastructure Minister and North Belfast MLA Nichola Mallon was at the Houben Centre for the event.She said: “With many others I was at the Houben Centre this morning for the @humefoundation peace building event where @simoncoveney#s speech was disrupted by a serious security threat."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ed .ece AUTOCROP h JPdevice.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ed .ece AUTOCROP h JPdevice.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ed .ece AUTOCROP h JPdevice.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ed .ece AUTOCROP h JPdevice.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "The scene at the The Houben Centre on Crumlin Road where a security alert is taking place. Threatening a peace building event - those behind this need to get it, you#ve lost, you won#t hold us back.”Alliance Party leader Naomi Long said it was “hard to imagine what goes through the minds of people who engage in such reckless, futile behaviour”.Hearing deeply concerning reports of a security incident at the Hume Foundation peace building event in N Belfast.Hard to imagine what goes through the minds of people who engage in such reckless, futile behaviour.Thoughts with all those disrupted and distressed as a result.— Naomi Long MLAMarch , DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson also said: “Good to see widespread condemnation of those behind the hijacking and security alert in North Belfast.“Most people want to get on with their lives and have no truck with those who cling to violence.”Good to see widespread condemnation of those behind the hijacking and security alert in North Belfast. Most people want to get on with their lives and have no truck with those who cling to violence.— Jeffrey Donaldson MPMarch , The Alliance North Belfast representative, Nuala McAllister, added to the condemnation.Alliance North Belfast representative Nuala McAllister has said those behind a security alert in North Belfast will not drag us back to the past, despite their actions.“My thoughts are with those who were at the Houben Centre and in Holy Cross Church during this incident,” said Councillor McAllister.“A relative of mine was in the church during this incident. Thankfully, they and others were safely removed and my thanks go to the security services for their work to do that. My thoughts are also with the driver of the van hijacked, who will have gone through a traumatic experience.”She said the “overwhelming reaction” from the people of North Belfast were disgusted by those behind the incident.“They can try and cause fear all they want but are not wanted here. title: p and o ship detained in larne after being deemed unfit to sail
story: PandO European Causeway ferry docked at Larne Port  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePandO European Causeway ferry docked at Larne Port By Catherine Wylie and Rebecca Black, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA ship operated by PO Ferries has been detained in Larne for being “unfit to sail”.The European Causeway vessel has been held in the Northern Ireland port due to “failures on crew familiarisation, vessel documentation and crew training”, the Maritime and Coastguard Agencysaid.Following my instruction to inspect all PO vessels prior to entering back into service, the @MCA_Media has detained a ship for being unfit to sail. I will not compromise the safety of these vessels and PO will not be able to rush inexperienced crew through training.— Rt Hon Grant Shapps MPMarch , Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said he will not compromise the safety of PO vessels and insisted that the company will not be able to rush training for inexperienced people.The company has sacked almost  seafarers and plans to replace them with agency staff on cheaper salaries.A spokesperson for the Maritime and Coastguard Agency said: “We can confirm that the European Causeway has been detained in Larne.“It has been detained due to failures on crew familiarisation, vessel documentation and crew training.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “The vessel will remain under detention until all these issues are resolved by PO Ferries. Only then will it be reinspected.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming ff .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cacbdc-c-ca-b-d_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming ff .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cacbdc-c-ca-b-d_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming ff .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cacbdc-c-ca-b-d_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming ff .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cacbdc-c-ca-b-d_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "PandO European Causeway ferry docked at Larne Port last week PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePandO European Causeway ferry docked at Larne Port last week The MCA said there were no passengers or freight on board the European Causeway vessel when it was detained.Mr Shapps tweeted: “Following my instruction to inspect all PO vessels prior to entering back into service, the @MCA_Media has detained a ship for being unfit to sail.“I will not compromise the safety of these vessels and PO will not be able to rush inexperienced crew through training.”The detention of ships is based on concerns over their safety and to prevent them going to sea.The European Causeway entered service in  replacing the Pride of Rathlin, according to the PO Ferries website.“Specically designed for our Cairnryan to Larne route, she has not operated where and has only been taken out of serviceshe needs a refit,” the website said.It comes as Prime Minister Boris Johnson backed Mr Shapps’ call for PO Ferries’ chief executive Peter Hebblethwaite to quit, over the sacking of  workers without notice.In Larne, the local mayor of the Mid and East Antrim Council, William McCaughey, said they would support the reinstatement of the staff immediately.“It is ridiculous what PO has done to the staff, we in Larne would be very keen to see staff reinstated, it is the least that PO could do,” he told the PA news agency.Labour’s shadow transport secretary Louise Haigh also called for the sacked workers to be reinstated and for Mr Hebblethwaite to be “barred” as a director for his role in the crisis.She wrote on Twitter: “The trained, experienced, loyal crew should be reinstated. And the Chief Executive should be barred as a director.“The shameful misconduct of PO Ferries has ruined livelihoods, and is harming the UK’s key shipping routes.”The trained, experienced, loyal crew should be reinstated.And the Chief Executive should be barred as a director.The shameful misconduct of PO Ferries has ruined livelihoods, and is harming the UK’s key shipping routes. https:t.co jnAAUNu— Louise HaighMarch , Labour has written to Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng asking whether the Government will seek the removal of Mr Hebblethwaite as a director under the Company Directors Disqualication Act .In a letter, the party accused the Government of “sitting on their hands” rather than taking action to hold PO to account, adding that the “toothless response risks giving the green light to exploitation”.Alliance East Antrim MLA Stewart Dickson welcomed the impounding of the ferry as a safety measure.“It’s not like the crew of an airplane getting off one Easyjet and getting on to the next one where the controls are the exactly the same, and everything is in the same place,” he told PA.“No two ships are the same, and you cannot just fly a crew in and expect them to be able to sail a ship. Every control will be in a dferent place, but particularly all those health and safety drills that have to be gone through, everything from leboat stations to how each item of equipment operates.“It seemed to me it was going to be very dficult for staff to be able to take on that role in such a short period of time.“I am absolutely delighted they have . This isn’t vengeance against PO, it’s about passenger safety and the safety of the crew as well.“It was reckless of the company to think they could not only act in the way in which they did about dismissing staff but they don’t seem to have had a plan as to how they were going to take this forward and now it is falling apart on them.”Meanwhile, the RMT union said it welcomed the detention of the European Causeway and it demanded the Government “seize the entire fleet” of PO vessels.General secretary Mick Lynch said: “The seizing of the European Causeway by the MCA tonight shows that the gangster capitalist outfit PO are not fit and proper to run a safe service after the jobs massacre.“This mob should be barred, their ships impounded and the sacked crews reinstated to get these crucial ferry routes back running safely.”Protests about PO’s actions are expected to take place in Liverpool, Hull and Dover on Saturday.Most ReadStormont department criticised for building Derry title: stormont department criticised for building derry park and ride which breaches planning rules
story: Anglers accuse minister of failure to admit mistakesExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseExtreme weather: Workmen removing cars from the River Faughan after flooding in . Credit: Kelvin Boyes Presseye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueExtreme weather: Workmen removing cars from the River Faughan after flooding in . Credit: Kelvin Boyes PresseyeGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Department for Infrastructurehas been strongly criticised for building a second park-and-ride facility on the outskirts of Londonderry in breach of planning conditions.The River Faughan Anglersgroup spoke out after Stormont’s Public AccountsCommittee said in a scathing report that it was “alarmed and appalled” at the abysmal performance of, and lack of transparency in, the planning system.In August , the DfI park-and-ride facility beside the A bridge over the River Faughan was damaged by flooding. Cars were swept into the river and people were rescued from the rising waters.It was then discovered it was operating without planning permission or environmental assessments.Read MoreWe live in fear, says mother of boy attacked ‘for being Protestant’Council rapped for spending £k on ‘fancy cameras’ for zoom meetingsThis was because what permission it had was temporary, and a condition required the facility’s removal and the restoration of the site by , a full year before the flooding struck. Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up In effect, DfI was breaching its planning permission.While the site is no longer operational, RFA said the department is still in breach because the facility was meant to be removed and the site restored by .In , DfI submitted an application for a new park-and-ride facility that opened on the edge of Drumahoe in August last year.RFA believes this facility should be rendered “unauthorised” because it is in breach of a planning condition which required it to submit additional environmental information to the planning authority and to have this agreed before any works commenced.RFA director Dean Blackwood said the department charged with upholding the integrity and credibility of the planning system continued to demonstrate why citizens had absolutely no trust in its ability to do so.“Expert consultees such as the Northern Ireland Environment Agencyand Shared Environmental Services, whose input into environmental planning matters is essential, both declined to provide that input because of the department’s unauthorised actions, which rendered the planning condition meaningless and ineffective,” he added.“While the department might seek to play down its unauthorised actions by claiming its dedicated environmental team was on site and did not raise any concern, that is contradicted by the fact that during construction works, RFA filmed an pollution incident on the Faughan on August , , coming from works associated with the park-and-ride.”Mr Blackwood also claimed it had proved dficult to get answers or an acknowledgement of mistakes. “That it took nine Assembly questions from Rachel Woods MLA, tabled over a period of more than a year, to elicit an admission from the minister that her department did, in fact, start work in breach of its planning condition, suggests to me that the public service principles of openness and transparency hold little value in this department,” he said.The DfI accepted it had powers and s that enabled it to monitor the operation of planning matters and to oversee and secure the implementation of regional policy and good practices.However, it claimed that the responsibility to do so ultimately rested with councils, and it did not want to interfere.Compliance with any planning application is the responsibility of the relevant council, the DfI also claimed.A spokesperson said the department did not take a decision to “intentionally commence works” before the required environmental information was agreed by the council.“The facility has been operational since July . In addition, the NIEA, along with the department’s consulting advisors and dedicated environmental team, were on site extensively during construction,” they added. “During this period, they did not raise any concern or issues relating to either the environmental controls or working methods adopted.”The local council confirmed it was aware of an alleged breach of conditions. A spokeswoman said: “A report of an alleged pollution incident was received. The council engaged with the DfI, the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs and NIEA officials on the matter.”Related topicsDepartment for InfrastructureNorthern Ireland title: uvf blamed for north belfast bomb hoax aimed at simon coveney
story: Police believe the UVF is behind a security alert that led to Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney being evacuated from a peace event in Belfast.Mr Coveney was delivering a speech when he was ushered from the room following reports a van had been hijacked and driven to the venue on Friday.A controlled explosion was carried out at the scene, and it was later declared a hoax.Secretary of State Brandon Lewis and Justice Minister Naomi Long led condemnation of what happened.The event at the Houben Centre on the Crumlin Road was organised by the John and Pat Hume Foundation.Sources say it was designed to send a “strong message” to the Irish Government over the Brexit protocol.Mr Coveney was midway through a speech to the audience of community leaders and Troubles victims when he was approached by a member of his security staff, led away and driven off in his ministerial car.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreAllison Morris:OpinionDramatic escalation amounts to an all-out war against NI ProtocolViolence, murder and gangsterism: Timeline of UVF activity since  Speaking at police headquarters on Friday night, PSNI Assistant Chief Constable Mark McEwan condemned the “disgraceful” attack.He said that between am and am a van was hijacked in Sydney Street West, off the Shankill Road.The driver was threatened by two gunmen and forced to drive the white Vauxhall vehicle a short distance to another street and a device was then placed in the back.The victim was forced to drive the van to Holy Cross Church.“Just think about this, the victim believed at this point he was driving a van containing a live bomb and that his family were being threatened,” Mr McEwan said.More than  homes were evacuated during the security alert, local schools were affected, and residents in a nursing home had to be moved to a dferent part of the building.A funeral taking place in the chapel was also disrupted.With the device declared a hoax, Mr McEwan said the goal of those responsible was to cause maximum disruption.He added: “At this early stage of the investigation our assessment is that these crimes were carried out by loyalist paramilitary groups. We are keeping an open mind at this stage but one of the primary lines of investigation is the UVF.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEmergency services attend security alertPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEmergency services attend security alertHe appealed for information on the gunmen and the movements of the van, registration XJZ .Mr McEwan said he would not speculate on whether Mr Coveney was the intended target, or whether he would require extra security in the future.He also could not be certain on whether the weapons used were real, but said the threat felt real to the driver.He said the driver had since been taken to hospital for treatment, and that a substantial security threat remained, meaning “an attack is likely”.Mr Coveney later posted on Twitter he was “saddened and frustrated that someone has been attacked and victimised in this way and my thoughts are with him and his family”.He also thanked the PSNI for its actions in evacuating the building.Family members at the funeral that was disrupted also told of their anger."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland afcf .ece AUTOCROP w _security_alert__.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland afcf .ece AUTOCROP w _security_alert__.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland afcf .ece AUTOCROP w _security_alert__.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland afcf .ece AUTOCROP w _security_alert__.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "Fr John Graven carries out a funeral service in the car Park at Holy Cross Church in North Belfast due to a security alert in the nearby Houben Centre  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFr John Graven carries out a funeral service in the car Park at Holy Cross Church in North Belfast due to a security alert in the nearby Houben Centre Sheila McDonald, whose late mother Bridie was being buried, told the BBC a deeply poignant and personal day had been ruined.“I was meant to be burying my mother today, and these eejits took that very special moment away from us,” she said.Mr Lewis said the incident was a reminder a small minority are willing to use violence to advance their goals.“My thoughts are with the driver who faced a terrying ordeal, the family that was holding a funeral, as well as with Simon Coveney and everyone  who was impacted,” he said.“These actions are reprehensible. “I utterly condemn those involved and give my thanks and reiterate my full support to the PSNI and security partners and urge anyone with any information to contact the police.” Read MoreNorth Belfast security alert: Watch moment Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney evacuated after vehicle hijackedNorth Belfast security alert: Loyalist bomb attack a hoax, PSNI believe UVF responsible for incident near event attended by Simon CoveneyThe Justice Minister condemned the “reckless actions” of those responsible.Mrs Long said: “Today, a man who left home to do a day’s work on a sunny Friday morning was threatened at gunpoint.“He was told his family was in danger and forced to drive what he thought was a live bomb to a church.“It must have been an utterly terrying experience.“Today, a grieving family had their last goodbye to their loved one disrupted,  homes were evacuated, and residents of a nursing home had to be moved from their rooms.“Those who orchestrated and planned this cruel and callous chain of events set out to cause maximum disruption and distress to people who were quite simply getting on with their lives.“They do not care about local communities, nor do they care about the distress and emotional trauma their reckless actions cause.“We have come too far to be dragged back in to the past and I would urge anyone with any information, no matter how insignicant it may seem, to contact the police or Crimestoppers.”The event had been organised by former SDLP councillor Tim Attwood on behalf of the John and Pat Hume Foundation, with Mr Coveney the keynote speaker. The foundation was sent up in  following the death of Mr Hume.Mr Coveney has been the target of loyalists in the past. His image was placed on anti-protocol banners displayed in some loyalist areas late last year. However, the latest attack signals an escalation in violent loyalist opposition to the Irish Sea border.DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson condemned the alert, saying: “Most people want to get on with their lives and have no truck with those who cling to violence”.Sinn Fein vice president Michelle O’Neill said she condemned the actions of “those involved in a security alert at an event focused on peace, reconciliation and finding common ground”. “Those determined to cause instability and disruption will not succeed,” she tweeted. “Those of us committed to peace will not be deterred.”Ulster Unionist leader Doug Beattie said it was “simply shocking”.“Apart from the irony that Mr Coveney was speaking about the suffering in Ukraine as part of his speech on reconciliation, a speech he can deliver again, a grieving family burying a loved one had to hold their funeral Mass outdoors, something that cannot be undone,” he said. “Relatives were denied their right to pay their respects as planned.” SDLP MP Claire Hanna, who was at the event, said: “The irony is lost on nobody that this was an event about reconciliation, about common ground with a genuinely erse audience of people. “That it has been disrupted in such an aggressive way is appalling.”Mr Attwood said the alert was a reminder “to everyone that there is no role in our society for violence”.Related topicsNaomi Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium LucidTalk boss defends election polling as a sign of Northern Ireland becoming ‘a normal society’LucidTalk boss says criticism of political surveys is unfairExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseA woman entering a polling station in east BelfastArlene Foster. Credit: Liam McBurneyLucidTalk’s Bill White FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA woman entering a polling station in east BelfastSuzanne BreenTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWhether you come to praise or bury opinion polls, there is no doubting the central position they are starting to occupy on the political landscape here.A LucidTalk survey for the Belfastlast February showed DUP support had fallen to % — the lowest in two decades. It spooked the party, a leadership challenge followed, and three months later Arlene Foster was gone.Polls increasingly appear to set the agenda. The TUV’s ratings rise has arguably led the DUP to harden its protocol stance and to collapse the Executive.The UUP’s strong showing in successive surveys since Doug Beattie took over has surely strengthened his hand with conservative elements in the party who otherwise might have publicly aired opposition to his liberal direction.Lacklustre ratings for the SDLP in both LucidTalk and a recent Irish News University of Liverpool poll — putting it on just % — cast a shadow over the party as it prepares for May’s Assembly election.“I think too much attention is given to polls in Northern Ireland,” Colum Eastwood said recently. That’s an entirely understandable complaint from his viewpoint.There’s a danger for the party that the polls become a self-fulfilling prophecy — the ‘loser’ label is fixed in the public mind before a single vote is cast.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up A key debate has long been whether polls simply measure public opinion or influence it.Some believe that the ‘bandwagon effect’ makes polls positively dangerous. Negative ratings are fatal as people’s preferences sht to whoever is ahead.Rather than making informed choices, voters conform to majority opinion. The subconscious desire to join the crowd, to be on the winning side, leads them to support parties with a high level of support.Some argue that rather than being just a tool to discover the wishes of the public, polls disrupt the democratic process. Critics claim that pollsters are too powerful.Bill White, who runs LucidTalk, robustly challenges that argument. “Did the DUP dump Arlene Foster on the basis of last February’s LucidTalk poll  No,” he said.“I would be very worriedI thought that seasoned political figures made decisions based purely on a poll. It may have been a spark that led to moves against her but that would have been because it chimed with what DUP people were already hearing on the ground.“Had it not matched what they were being told on doorsteps it wouldn’t have been taken seriously. Polls have to feel right.”There are numerous large polling organisations in Britain. LucidTalk and Social Market Research, which conducted the Irish News University of Liverpool poll, are two Belfast-based companies carrying out political polling here.White, who worked in market research and IT in London and Dublin, set up LucidTalk in .“Online polling came to London in the late s. About a decade later, I thought it was a good thing to start here,” he said.White was “greatly encouraged” by Liam Clarke, the late and highly respected political editor of the Belfast : “Liam would conduct his own informal polling at party conferences, asking delegates for their views on a range of topical issues.“He was very data-driven and thought online polling with a really good sample size would be a big step forward.“By , nearly everybody had a computer or laptop and an email address. The great thing about online polling was its confidentiality and that’s so important in a place like Northern Ireland.“You do it in your own home, and you do it directly. You remove all human interaction. When you vote somebody hands you a ballot, but you mark it in the privacy of a polling booth.“Nobody knows your views unless you choose to tell them. Polling benefits when the same approach applies.”While occasional opinion polls were carried out in Northern Ireland during the Troubles, White says regular and political polling would have been impossible for a local company as the conflict raged.“Somebody would have threatened to blow your head offthey didn’t like the results, particularlyit concerned a contentious and emotional an issue like the border” he said..“I get a bit of grief on social media nowadays. Somebody recently told me: ‘Be careful you don’t get a knock on the door’.“Imagine what a pollster would have endured in the Seventies and Eighties here “It would have been only a small minority getting upset, but it would have been a very dangerous minority.”White says many other problems would have plagued pollsters during the Troubles: “With no internet, face-to-face polling would have been necessary.“It would have been challenging for interviewers to go into republican or loyalist areas, knock on doors, and ask people who they were planning to vote for. A lot of doors would have been slammed in a lot of faces.“In other cases, people would have been reluctant to tell the truth about who they were voting for because they wouldn’t want to offend the interviewer.“They would have been reserved for fear of hurting the feelings of the questioner. Other folk would just have been genuinely nervous about opening up.“It’s a sign of how Northern Ireland is progressing to a normal society, how the situation is calmer and more settled, that we actually can conduct regular polling on political issues.”The few polls that were carried out during the conflict, and in the decade after the ceasefires, often signicantly under-estimated support for the DUP, and particularly Sinn Fein.A survey just before the  Westminster election put Sinn Fein on %. It secured a % vote.A poll ahead of the  Assembly election put the DUP and Sinn Fein both on %. They secured % and % respectively.The existence of the ‘shy’ Sinn Fein or DUP voter — reluctant to say they voted for a party considered extreme — skewed many polls.In Britain, politicians have made fatal mistakes based on polling.Theresa May opted for an early election in April  when the Tories’ average poll lead over Labour was % points. Fty days later, a general election resulted in a hung Parliament.White believes much criticism of polling is unfair: “Pollsters don’t have super powers, we don’t predict the future.“A poll is only a snapshot in time. You treat a poll like the weather forecast.“It says ‘Showers in North Down’, so you take an umbrella, but you don’t knowit’s actually going to be raining at precisely .pm when you’re visiting Aunt Mabel in Bangor. Polls are about identying trends.”White warns that polls struggle much more with the outcome of referenda than elections.“A referendum campaign is entirely dferent to an election campaign,” he added.“It’s big and unknown. You’re spinning the roulette wheel. In Scotland the pro-independence campaign started on % — it was neck-and-neck near the end of the campaign. If a border poll was called here nobody knows how it would go. There are countless factors that could influence how it developed. So many people who never voted in elections would likely turn out.”Related topicsLucidTalk pollArlene FosterTraditional Unionist VoiceNI ProtocolThe Executive OfficeUlster Unionist PartyDoug Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumUnionism remains as ided in  as it was in , now it might be too late to do things dferentlyAlex KaneFty years on from the closing of Northern Ireland’s House of Commons and the problems look much the same for unionism, writes Alex KaneExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePicture taken during the last sitting NI House of Commons. Faulkner and other Cabinet ministers address a mass rally of Vanguard supporters from the balcony of StormontThe Prime Minister Brian Faulkner with members of his cabinet in . Credit: Charles CockcroftStormont. Credit: Kevin Scott   Belfast  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePicture taken during the last sitting NI House of Commons. Faulkner and other Cabinet ministers address a mass rally of Vanguard supporters from the balcony of StormontMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAt .pm, on March , , Northern Ireland’s House of Commons adjourned. It was never to meet again. Two days later the NI Temporary Provisions Act became law, introducing direct rule, ending  years of unionist government, bringing devolution to a stop and shutting down NI’s Parliament. It was the biggest crisis for unionism since the  Home Rule Bill.At lunchtime on March , Brian Faulkner, destined to be NI’s last Prime Minister, led his Cabinet onto the balcony to address the enormous crowdwhich had gathered in the grounds. He had only a loudspeaker.“People of Ulster, I am speaking to you still as Prime Minister of Northern Ireland. I want to say, not just on my own behalf, but on behalf of every one of my colleagues in the Government and the Parliamentary Party here at Stormont, that we understand absolutely the feelings which have persuaded you to come out to Parliament Buildings today… we share the resentment that you feel. We have tremendous power.“Our power is the power of our numbers our power is the justice of our cause our power is the responsibility of our conduct. Let us never play the game of the murderers of the IRA. Let us show the world that, so far as we are concerned, violence and intimidation are out. British we are and British we remain!”The previous day Faulkner had addressed an emergency meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council, informing it that his government had lost confidence in Edward Heath’s administration.By his own admission it was an angry meeting seething at what was regarded as a betrayal and surrender to unionism’s enemies. But he also warned them to shun violent responses and rely, instead, on the ‘Unionist veto’ which lay in the strength of their numbers.Exactly  years later, on Monday March , the present Assembly will be dissolved in preparation for an election on May . There are many within the unionist community who believe that, like its predecessor on March , , this institution will not meet again.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Political unionism is again seething with anger, believing that another Conservative government has betrayed it and rolled over to the demands of those who want Northern Ireland removed from the United Kingdom. Indeed, they would argue that the process of removal has been advanced by a protocol which traps Northern Ireland in some sort of constitutional halfway house between Great Britain, the Republic of Ireland and the European Union.When Brian Faulkner spoke of unionism relying on the strength of its numbers it was at a time when the combined pro-Union vote hovered around two-thirds of the overall vote.At the election for the first post-NI Parliament Assembly, in June , the pro-Union votewas %. In the  Assembly election that votehad reduced to .%.That election also saw unionism reduced to a minority within an NI Parliament and Assembly: and there is now a possibility, come May , that unionism won’t even have the numbers to qualy for the position of First Minister.And yet unionism remains as ided now as it was back in . The narrowing of the demographic gap between unionism and nationalism, along with an ongoing reluctance by successive British governments to be seen to be what might be described as pro-active on behalf of unionism, hasn’t pushed it in the direction of prioritising a coherent, collective, long-term strategy for survival.Even the thundering hammer-blows rained down on the DUP by Boris Johnson continue to be greeted with fairly mild responses from the party leadership.Speaking on Monday evening Jeffrey Donaldson acknowledged the problem: “It’s not a question of throwing the DUP under the bus. The Prime Minister threw Northern Ireland under the bus and the harm that this protocol has done to Northern Ireland is, I think, something the Prime Minister now recognises. But we need him to do something about it.”The problem, of course, is that Donaldson has been saying this since September last yearand Johnson has done nothing. He’ll continue to do nothing until May : and, in all likelihood, will do nothing after that, either.In March  Brian Faulkner and the UUP decided to risk the collapse of the NI Parliament rather than allow control of security to pass from the NI government to Westminster.A few days before Stormont was prorogued Faulkner had written to Edward Heath: ‘We wish to point out with a sense of the heavy responsibility involved that the imposition of this proposal, involving as it will the resignation of the Government of Northern Ireland as a whole, may have the gravest consequences, the full extent of which cannot now be foreseen.’We now know the primary consequence of the resignation and subsequent prorogation: the end of majority rule, the introduction of mandatory power-sharingand the sapping of unionist confidence that their future position within the United Kingdom was, to all intents and purposes, secure.What Faulkner did — although I fully understand why he had to do it — was hand over the political negotiating process to a British government which was determined to build an entirely dferent relationship with its Irish counterpart.In his biography, Memoirs of a Statesman , Faulkner hinted at regrets: “... when unionists of vision tried to stimulate new thinking and broaden the appeal of unionism in the s s I did not come out and support them. I did not think they were achieving anything useful...but we should have spent more time watering the roots of tolerance.“We did not take the initiative in reforming our society until events forced change on us. By  we were reacting to events rather than controlling them and one was always conscious of running very fast merely to make up lost ground.’Since then, a number of other unionist loyalist leaders have voiced fairly similar regrets. Sometimes about their own personal lack of foresight and sometimes about opportunities which unionism may have missed over the decades.Yet as Faulkner noted, there was always a sense that unionism was a few steps behind the thinking of others when it came to mapping out Northern Ireland’s post- future. Or, as former UUP leader Reg Empey put it, “every time unionism walks from the table it inevitably and iniably s to another table with a weaker hand”.In the early s a Minister of State based in the NIO told me: “The problem with unionism — and it’s a particular problem for those outside Northern Ireland who try to understand it — is that there are far too many ieties. They spend as much time complaining about their unionist rivals as they do complaining about their more specic political and constitutional opponents.”From until the collapse of Stormont in  the isions could mostly be controlled by the mantra — ‘United we stand. Divided we fall.’ But once the fall came there was nothing to hold unionism together and it splintered and continues to splinter.Faulkner and power-sharing were destroyed by the United Ulster Unionist Council in . Shortly afterwards the ious members of the UUUC — who couldn’t come up with an agreed alternative to the Sunningdale deal — turned on themselves.The UUP descended into civil war between -. The loyalist paramilitary groups, essential to the ‘selling’ of the Good Friday Agreement, have now withdrawn support for it. The DUP has had a horrible  months and is still beset with internal dficulties.A growing element of younger loyalism is pushing its anti-protocol campaigning towards prioritising the final collapse of the GFA institutions. And Jeffrey Donaldson and Jim Allisterhave laid down pre-election preconditions on both the protocol and the eventuality of a Sinn Fein First Minister.Change a few names and organisations and we could be talking about that period from March  to May  — when unionism and loyalism were struggling to find a route map from the crisis forced on them by widespread political societal instability and British governments which were determined to impose change upon them.But here’s the reality:the strategies and policies adopted by unionists didn’t work back then, why does anyone think terribly similar strategies and policies would work today: particularly when the constitutional crisis is worse now than then and the shadow of a border poll is hanging over every aspect of the coming election.A British state paper released in  had this assessment of the  Assembly election: ‘Mr Faulkner’s position is undoubtedly dficult. He will have less than half of the Protestant vote behind him, as Dr Paisley and others will no doubt vocerously remind him,and when he makes an effort to work the new system.“It was always to be anticipated that the Protestant vote would be fragmented… but the outcome has left the potential accepters weaker and the ‘wreckers’ stronger than expected.’Something very similar happened to David Trimble in , allowing his internal and external opponents to destroy him. Might the same thing be about to happen to Jeffrey Donaldson  Between  and  the DUP vote represented a majority of unionist votes cast — but even then, the party had to temper a lot of decisions and steer away from potential compromises and concessions. If the DUP doesn’t represent the majority of unionist votes cast and seats won in the Assembly on May  it will make it very dficult for Donaldson to reboot the executive.We seem to be on ‘the more things change, the more they stay the same’ territory for unionism. Again. But there is one dference. I was in that crowd in the grounds of Stormont on March , , a few months short of my th birthday.I recognised the scale of the shock: but I also recognised something , a new opportunity for unionism to do things dferently. My big fear today — and I’m very pessimistic, by the way, about a rebooted Assembly— is that unionism may have left it too late to do things dferently.Related topicsIRAAlliance PartyBoris JohnsonSir
